Colin said that I said that he said that...

> >Sort of.  All I really mean is that all rotations and transforms of a board
> >are actually identical and have the same correct move.  So there is no need
> >for your net to learn them each separately.  I've need doing to analysis of
> >TTT and to avoid processing identical boards twice I've simply:
> >
> >1) define each board as a base-3 code number (top-left is first digit,
> >top-middle is second..., empty = 0, cross = 1, naught = 2)
> >2) when a board appears calculate than number for each of its 8 transforms
> >3) then file and process the board only under the _lowest_ of those codes
> >
> >
>I'm having trouble decoding your english, I think your brain is working
>faster than you can type :) I get the essence of what you're suggesting,
>I suppose it's a little like the ego-centric agent idea where you
>effectively reduce the number of input signal combinations by ensuring
>that the agent is always oriented in a certain way with respect to some
>object of interest. Here you are collapsing the complete set of possible
>board states into a more compact set that still represents the same
>number of strategic states.

Exactly.

>Actually if this concept could be applied to
>the 'Go' board state then we might have the basis of a real advance in
>AI Go playing - something of a holy grail.

It can be applied to Go, but I think it helps a _lot_ less than you 
imagine.  e.g. there are somewhere in the region of 2^350 Go board configs 
and this reduces it by a bit under 8 fold....  Now if we could exploit the 
translation and rotation of _parts_ of the Go board...

> >So the simplest way I would remove mirroring and rotation from a network's
> >consideration would be just to do the same thing.  Always transform the
> >board to its lowest coded variant before showing it to the network.
> >
>This idea sounds vaguely like a technique used in designing logic
>circuits or something. I almost get it but I think I need to absorb some
>concrete examples.

OK, lets look at a 2x2 board.  There are four cells, which we can label 
with letters:

a b
c d

And each cell has a value 0 (empty), 1(X) or 2 (O) these values are 
unrelated to ANN input values...

Any board can be encoded as a base-3 number using a function:

Code = a + 3 * b * 9 * c + 27 * d

So an empty board has a code of zero, and

X _
_ _  = 1

_ X
_ _ = 3

_ _
O _ = 18

etc etc.

So, to find a "canonical" form for any board, all we do is calculate this 
value for every flip/rotate of the board and then choose the one with the 
lowest code.

So, for this:

X O
_ O = 33

_ X
O O = 65

O _
O X = 47

O O
X _ = 17

X _
O O = 63

_ O
X O = 69

O O
_ X = 35

O X
O _ = 23

So code:17 is chosen to represent all of these boards and networks which 
are about to be presented with any board in this set actually gets shown 
that one.

It doesn't matter how you select the canonical board, any consistent 
approach will do.  Obviously there may be some benefit to the networks if 
the boards are chosen with some sort of systematic approach and for that 
this way is quite good, because it is equivalent to attempting to place as 
the filled squares first at the top, and then on the right.  You can even 
tweak the encoding to give even more geometric choices, as long as no 
ambiguities (boards with the same code) are introduced.

In practise, you might want to encode using 0 (empty), 1 (me), 2 (him) and 
-1 might be better for the last case so that enemy pieces tend to get 
sorted to the opposite corner.
